app.note: G. Vijayavenugopal proposed to interpret poṉṉum as gold and take the previous word mīṉa as a mistake for īḻa (īḻam, Śrī Laṅkān gold). However, I do not think the mention of gold here would make sense. There are a few other possibilities, although none of them are entirely sactifactory: 1) pōṉṉum: "inside this land where the fishes (mīṉ) go (pōṉṉum) / inside this land where the elevation (mīṉ>mī) goes (pōṉṉum)"; 2) poṉṉum as a mistake for poḷḷum (digging): "inside this land where the elevated (mī) path (ṉa > naṭai) was dug (poḷḷum). This second possibility is based on a similar formula found in #7 : Ikkuḷattiṉ minaṭai poḷḷak kuḷattile kalluvatākavum. I have translated it as: we have to clear (kalluvatākavum) in the tank (kuḷattilē), in order to dig (poḷḷa) [for] an elevated (mī) road/path (naṭai) of this tank (ikkuḷattiṉ).
Literally: "the inner lake (aka-v-ēri-y-um) and the outer lake (puṟa-v-ēri-y-um)". It probably refers to a type of land, but the details remain unclear. See also #7 which has a similar formula.
Restoration based on the parallel in #2, line 4.
Literally: "the inner lake (aka-v-ēri-y-um) and the outer lake (puṟa-v-ēri-y-um)". This probably refers to a type of land, but the details remain unclear. See also #7 for a similar formula.

Dr. G. Vijayavenugopal (personal communication) suggested us to interpret poṉṉum as "gold", to read the previous word as mīṉa as a mistake for īḻa (īḻam), and to understand the phrase as "Lankan gold". We tentatively take the phrase in the sense of the "gold of fish", that is, the donation includes the income form the fishes of the two lakes just mentioned.
